SIR-xde (Susceptible-Infected-Recovered) Human Model

X-SIR.Rmd

The SIR (Susceptible-Infected-Recovered) human xde model model fulfills the generic interface of the human population component. It is the simplest model of endemic diseases in humans with recovery.

We subdivide a population into susceptible (SS) infected and infectious (II) and recovered (RR) individuals, where the total population is H=S+I+R.H = S+I+R. We assume the force of infection (hh, FoI) is linearly proportional to the EIR: h=b×EIR.h = b \times EIR. In its general form, with births (B(H)B(H)) and deaths (at the per-capita rate μ\mu), the generalized SIR_xde dynamics are:

Ṡ=−hS+B(H)−μSİ=hS−rI−μIṘ=rI−μR \begin{array}{rl} \dot{S} &= -h S + B(H) -\mu S\\ \dot{I} &= h S - rI - \mu I\\ \dot{R} &= rI-\mu R \end{array} We are assuming that a population could be stratified, such that the variables and parameter are all vectors with length nStrata.

Equilibrium Solutions

This model would have no interesting dynamics at equilibrium as the total population HH would tend to the recovered population RR.

Example 

library(ramp.xds)
library(ramp.library)
library(deSolve)
library(data.table)
library(ggplot2)

Using Setup

Here we use ramp.xds::xds_setup to set up the model object. We solve the model to equilibrium and check with the analytic steady state using the ramp.xds::xde_steady_state and compare the results.

test_SIR <- xds_setup(MYZname ="macdonald", Xname="SIR")
xds_solve(test_SIR, 365*10)-> test_SIR
unlist(list_Xvars(test_SIR$outputs$last_y, test_SIR, 1)) -> out1

Using the ramp.xds::xde_steady_state 

foi_eq = test_SIR$Xpar[[1]]$b*tail(test_SIR$outputs$terms$EIR,1)
xde_steady_state_X(1/365, 1000, test_SIR$Xpar[[1]]) -> out2

Then we compare the analytic and numerical solution

sum(abs(out2 - out1))
#> Warning in out2 - out1: longer object length is not a multiple of shorter
#> object length
#> [1] 1000
